compound-subject.compound-subject-part: Focus on Materials for Energy, Environment, and Healthcare

title-group.article-title: Examination of the mechanical and physical characteristics of geopolymer composites reinforced with sisal fibers

contrib-group.aff: 1Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Arba Minch University, Arba Minch, Ethiopia
2Renewable Technology Research Center, Arba Minch University, Arba Minch, Ethiopia

license.license-p: Original content from this work may be used under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 licence. Any further distribution of this work must maintain attribution to the author(s) and the title of the work, journal citation and DOI.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: This paper aims to investigate and characterize lightweight sisal fiber(SF)-reinforced geopolymer composite (SFRGC) materials to utilize instead of cement-based construction materials. The investigation targets the impact of independent factors on the compressive, splitting tensile strength, and water absorption of fiber-reinforced geopolymer composite. A Response Surface Methodology(RSM) with box Behnken design(BBD) was used for characterization and to obtain the significance level of the selected variables such as fiber volume (5%, 10%, and 15%), fiber length in mm (5, 20, and 35), and alkali concentration (8 M, 12 M, and 16 M). Best result for compressive strength was 21.5 Mpa with a respective interaction of variables fiber volume, fiber length, and alkali concentration (5%, 20 mm, and 8 M). The best result for splitting tensile strength was 4.6 Mpa respective interaction of variables of (15%, 35 mm, and 12 M) respectively. Best result for water absorption was 5.325% with the interaction of variables of (5%, 20 mm, and 8 M).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Ordinary Portland cement (OPC) is among the most commonly utilized structural materials on earth. Estimates suggest that 2.2 billion tons will be produced in the next few years [1]. However, the OPC manufacturing industries are responsible for 8% of global CO2 emissions. Consequently, there is an urgent need to develop new alternative binders with lower environmental and energy costs [2].

Geopolymers are composed of alkali solution and aluminosilicate materials. GGBFS and FA are prime examples of Aluminosilicate materials, which are industrial wastes capable of polluting air, water, and damaging human respiratory organs [3]. The alkaline solution is incorporated into Aluminosilicate materials to create the amorphous structure of AlO4 and SiO4 molecules that are connected with oxygen atoms. The most commonly used alkali solutions in the geopolymerization process are sodium hydroxide and sodium silicate or potassium hydroxide and potassium silicate [4].

Due to their superior mechanical strength, chemical durability, improved fire resistance [5], higher impact resistance [6], and enhanced bond strength performance, Geopolymer are utilized in structural applications [7].

Geopolymer have established it as a common substitute for Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC) [8, 9]. Despite its brittleness, fibers have been introduced to improve the tensile strength, flexural strength, fracture toughness, weight reduction, and corrosion resistance of geopolymers [9]. Although high-strength synthetic fibers such as carbon, glass, and basalts are favored for reinforcement, their use is restricted by environmental factors [10].

Indeed, natural fibers hold several advantages over commonly used synthetic fibers [11]. They are harmless, easy to handle, renewable, and inexpensive. The most prevalent natural fibers are plants fibers. Hemp, Sisal, Kenaf, cotton, sheep wool, coconut, and other natural fibers are instances [12]. SF is widely used in various applications, can be easily grown in many parts of the world [13].

The mechanical and physical properties of the SFRGC materials rely on several factors, the source of aluminosilicate material used in geopolymers can greatly affect the final properties of the material [14]. Each source has different chemical compositions, particle sizes, and reactive components, which can impact the setting time, strength, and durability of the final geopolymer composite [15, 16].

Fiber volume in composites enhances mechanical properties like tensile strength, flexural strength, and impact resistance. Fibers reinforcements in the composite, improving structural integrity, ductility, and toughness. Higher fiber volumes can reduce porosity, leading to a denser composite with improved thermal and acoustic properties. Balancing fiber volume between 10â30% is recommended for optimal performance [17].

The fiber length in composite materials plays a significant role in determining their mechanical and physical properties. The longer the fibers, the better the reinforcement and distribution within the matrix, which can enhance the strength and stiffness of the composite. However, if the fibers are too long, they may become entangled and cause processing issues, as well as negatively impact the overall performance of the composite [18]. Generally, for composites, a fiber length in the range of 10â30 mm is considered ideal. This length allows for good dispersion and alignment of fibers within the matrix, resulting in enhanced mechanical properties [19].

The principal objective of this study was to delineate and scrutinize the influence of specifically chosen control variables on the mechanical and physical attributes of SF Reinforced Geopolymer Composite (SFRC) material. From a literary perspective [20], it is evident that the mechanical and physical properties [21], including compressive and splitting tensile strength, as well as water absorption of geopolymers reinforced with natural fibers, are intricately contingent upon factors such as the percentage of fiber volume [22], fiber length, and alkali concentration expressed in molarity [23].

sec.title: Sisal fiber (SF)
sec.p: The SF used in this study was originated from the northern Ethiopian highlands. The measured density of the fiber, conducted using a pycnometer, approximates 1.4 g cmâ3. The modulus of elasticity for SF spans between 9 GPa and 19 GPa, while the tensile strength fluctuates from 347 MPa to 577 MPa based on the strain gaugeâs length.

sec.title: Fly ash
sec.p: Sub-bituminous coals, which are the type of coals employed in the current work, are found in Ethiopia. Consequently, the resultant (FA), classified as low calcium (class F), was used as an aluminosilicate [24].

sec.title: Alkali activators
sec.p: The alkaline solution was a blend of aqueous sodium hydroxide at concentrations of 8 M, 12 M, and 16 M, combined with sodium silicate, featuring a bulk density of 1350 kg mâ3 and a Na2SiO3/NaOH ratio ranging from 0.75 to 1.5. [25].

sec.title: Experimental design by response surface methodology (RSM)
sec.p: RSM techniques employed to develop, modify, optimize, and to determine the effects and significance of control variables, [26].

The relationship between the response and variables is expressed in equations (1) and (2). 1
Y=Î²+âi=1kÎ²ixi+âi=1kâ1âj=i+1kÎ²ixixj+âi=1kÎ²ijxi2
2
Y=Î²+Î²1x1+Î²2x2+â
where

are control variables,

Y, represents response,

Represent the unknown dependant parameters. 3

where

represents average values employed [27].

In this study, the Box-Behnken design(BBD) is selected due to its efficiency in terms of fewer runs compared to other methods. 4
N=K2+K+CO
Where K = is numbers variables, CO = numbers of mid points, N = number of sample for each response. But in this stady k = 3 and CO = 1, then the N = 13. The thirteen sample for each response are with different fiber volume, fiber length, and alkali concentration were produced.

sec.title: Preparation of SFRGC samples
sec.p: The SF underwent extraction, washing, and subsequent drying at room temperature prior to being prepared at the required length. The sodium hydroxide solution was meticulously prepared in the chemical laboratory, achieving optimal concentrations of 8 M, 12 M, and 16 M. Each molarity of sodium hydroxide solution underwent a reaction with the water solution of sodium silicate 24 h prior to the mixing process. The FA and SF, adhering to the specified ratio, were manually mixed with the optimum amount of alkali solution.

The resulting mixture was then placed into metallic molds and compacted using a metallic rod. Each of the thirteen specimens possessed its unique ratio of SF volume percentage, SF length, and alkali solution. The cylindrical mold dimensions were 8 cm in diameter and 15 cm in length, Whereas the cubic mold measured 10 cm on each side. After filling the molds, loading with a weight of 12 kg for a duration of 24 h, the specimens were demolded and left to dry at room temperature for 28 days before conducting tests [28], the specific ratio of mixtures was presented in table 1.

caption.p: Design preparation details of FA based SFRGC.

sec.title: Test methods
sec.p: The splitting tensile strength testing was performed using a splitting tensile strength testing machine, following the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) C496 standard. Splitting tensile strength tests were conducted with a sample length-to-diameter ratio of 2.0. The cylindrical sample is laid horizontally, and a radial load is applied to the cylinderâs face, resulting in the initiation of a straight crack along the circumference of the sample.

Compressive strength testing was conducted using a compression machine, following the ASTM C39â9623 standard. The testing machine was prepared before the testing process by adjusting the machineâs jaws and the specimen area. The load, to be applied, was inserted through a data-inserting key, and the load was directly applied until the specimen broke. The strength at the last points of sample failure was recorded Kilo Newton (kN).

General procedures for conducting the water absorption test of SFRGC followed the ASTM C 1585 standard. Initially, the weight of the sample after 28 days of curing was measured. Subsequently, test specimens were dried in an oven at 105 Â°C for 24 h. The weight of the oven-dried specimens was measured and recorded. The specimens were then immersed in water for a 24-hour duration, and the weight after immersion was measured and recorded.

The water absorption behavior of SFRGC was evaluated according to equation (5). 5
Waterabsorption=MwâMoMox100%
Where :
Mw,
weight of specimens after water immersion,
Mo
,weight of specimens after oven dry.

sec.title: RSM result and analysis of samples
sec.p: Experimental results of compressive, splitting tensile strength and water absorbtion were gained from BBD are presented in graphical chart as shown in figures 1(A), (B), and (C).

caption.p: The plot of (A) compressive strength (B) splitting tensile strength of each sample and (C) water absorption versus each sample.

sec.title: Model fitting and statistical analysis of compressive strength
sec.p:
For the compressive strength, the model of regression equations represented in equation (6), which is the predicted values can be obtained from. 6
CompressivestrengthY=+19.00â5.31Aâ0.6250Bâ1.94C+0.6250AB+0.125BCâ4.62A2â0.2500B2â0.3750Câ20.3750C2

sec.title: ANOVA for Quadratic model of compressive strength of SFRGC
sec.p: The validity of the models and the effects of each variable on the required response was tested with analysis of variance (ANOVA). The significance and effects of the control variables were examined by the p-value and F-value. P-values less than 0.0500 indicate model terms are significant. P-values greater than 0.05000 indicate the model terms are not significant. In model signal to noise ratio is greater than 4, whichis 51.224 which indicates an adequate signal.

As shown in table 2, ANOVA analysis of the compressive strength in response surface quadratic model. The P-values (0.0002) which indicates that model terms are significant for the quadratic regression model. It could be seen from table 2, that the effects of volume of SF (A) and alkaline concentration in Molarity(C) are highly significant compared to the first-order effect of SF length (B) and interaction of SF volume and SF length.

caption.p: ANOVA data of compressive strength obtained from BBD.

sec.p: An interaction of fiber length and SF volume (AB) was statistically significant because, p-values (p < 0.05). The second order effect of fiber volume percentage (A) is much significant. Optimum set of variables were found to maximize the compressive strength of SFRGC from quadratic model equations. Optimum set of control variables are 5%, 20 mm and 8 M, fiber volume, fiber length and alkali concentration respectively. The compressive strength under the evaluated optimum experimental conditions was 21.5 MPa, which was in very good agreement with the predicted value of 21.25.

sec.title: Response surface plots of compressive strength
sec.p: Figure 2 (3D) plots which depict the effect and interaction of variables in the compressive strength of SFRGC. The effect of control variables on the compressive strength of SFRGC is shown in figure 2(a). The figures were produced by using two variables at the same time by fixing the third variable at the center point. The compressive strength versus fiber volume percentage and fiber length with a fixed alkali concentration.

caption.p: 3D response surface plot (a,c,e) and contour plots (b,d,f) indicating the effects of the deter-mining variables on compressive strength.

sec.p: The compressive strength of SFRGC decreases as the fiber volume percentage increases from 5% to 15% and the fiber length increases from 5 mm to 35 mm. This influence is attributed to their impact on the transmission of stress from the binder to the SFs and the effectiveness with which the fibers resist deformation and fracture.

Certainly, in composite materials made of a matrix and fibers, the efficiency of stress transmission is impacted by the length of the fibers. Longer fibers tend to enhance stress transmission between the matrix and fibers, which might sound positive initially. However, this increased stress transmission can lead to a decrease in the overall strength of the composite. This weakening occurs because longer fibers can form clusters or agglomerations, creating points of stress concentration within the material [14].

Figure 2(b) illustrate that, with a fixed fiber volume, the compressive strength slightly declines with an increase in fiber length from 5 mm to 35 mm. Conversely, the compressive strength increases as the alkaline concentration decreases from 16 M to 8 M. This phenomenon is due to the elevated concentration of the alkaline activator, which raises the pH of the activating fluid. Optimal aluminosilicate dissolution, as suggested by various publications, occurs at pH values between 13 and 14. Previous research has established a correlation between higher pH values and increased compressive strength in geopolymer concrete [23].

In figure 2(c), the relationship between compressive strength and fiber volume percentage, as well as alkali concentration with a fixed fiber length, is depicted. The compressive strength decreases with an increase in alkali concentration from 8 M to 16 M and also decreases with an increase in fiber volume percentage from 5% to 15%.

sec.title: Model fitting and statistical analysis of splitting tensile strength
sec.p:
For the spiliting tensile strength, the model of regression equations represented in equation (7). 7
SplittingtensilestrengthY=3.30+1.55A+0.275Bâ0.45Câ0.2ABâ0.3ACâ0.225A2â0.075B2â0.975C2

sec.title: ANOVA for Quadratic model of splitting tensile of SFRGC
sec.p: As presented in table 3, the significance and effects of all the independent variables of the model was examined by p-value, and F- value. For the splitting tensile strength, interaction of control variables A, B, C, AB, BC and C2 are significant model terms. P-values less than 0.05000 indicate the model terms are significant. The signal-to-noise ratio in this model is 39.33 indicates an adequate signal.

caption.p: ANOVA for quadratic model of splitting tensile strength.

sec.p: The tensile strength under the evaluated optimum experimental conditions was 4.6 Mpa, which is in very good agreement with the predicted value of 4.625, which suggests that the model was reliable. Optimum set of control variables at that point is 15% of fiber volume, 35 mm fiber length and 12 M of alkali concentration.

sec.title: Response surface plots splitting tensile strength
sec.p: The figure 3 (3D) plots which depicts the effect and interaction of variables in the splitting tensile strength of SFRGC. As shown in figure 3(a), the splitting tensile strength versus fiber volume percentage and fiber length with a fixed alkali concentration, it shows that the tensile strength increases when fiber volume increase from 5% to 15% and fiber length from 5 mm to 35 mm.

caption.p: 3D response surface plot (a, b, c) indicating the effects of the determining variables on splitting tensile strength (Y).

sec.p: At a very low fiber volume percentage, the microstructural body was very compacted and the porosity inside the composite was decrease, therefore splitting tensile decrease. However, variable interaction indicated that interaction of short fiber length, low fiber volume percentage and medium alkali concentration results in reduction of splitting tensile strengths.

The effect of sisal length and alkali concentration on the splitting tensile strength of SFRGC is shown in figure(b). The splitting tensile strength was decreased by increasing the fiber length from 5 mm to 35 mm whereas splitting tensile strength increased as in-crease in alkaline concentration from 8 M to 12 M and again decrease as increase in alkali concentration from 12 M to 16 M.

As shown in figure 3(c), the effect of sisal volume percentage and alkali concentration on the splitting tensile strength, by fixing the SF length, show that the tensile strength decrease as increase in fiber volume percentage from 5% to 15%.

sec.title: Model fitting and statistical analysis of water absorption of SFRGC.
sec.p:
For the water absorbtion, the model of regression equation represented in equation (8). 8
WaterabsorptionY=10.00+2.43A+1.16B+1.62C+0.375ABâ0.4188ACâ0.5219A2â0.4156B2â0.3531C2

sec.title: ANOVA for quadratic model of water absorption of SFRGC
sec.p: As presented in table 4, The significance of all the independent variables of the model was examined by p-value, and F- value. In this case A, B, C, AB, BC, AC, A2, B2 and C2 are significant model terms. Furthermore, the signal-to-noise ratio, exceeds the desirable threshold at 39.3326, indicating a highly adequate signal.

caption.p: ANOVA for quadratic model water absorption.

sec.title: Response surface plots water absorption
sec.p: Figure 4(a), presents 3D plots illustrating the influence and interactions concurrently manipulating two variables while maintaining the third variable at the center point. Specifically, the water absorption was analyzed concerning fiber volume percentage and fiber length, while keeping the alkali concentration constant.

The water absorption exhibited an increase as the fiber volume percentage rose from 5% to 15% and the fiber length from 5 mm to 35 mm. This behavior can be attributed to the infiltration of water molecules into SFRGC through three distinct mechanisms : diffusion of moisture content within the micro-gaps between polymer chains, capillary transport into the micro-gaps, and flaws in the interfaces between the fibers and the matrix. The highest water absorption of SFRGC, at 13.5%, was attained at an optimal variable set comprising a fiber volume percentage of 15%, fiber length of 20 mm, and an alkaline concentration of 16 M. However, it is noteworthy that the interaction of variables also plays a significant role in percentage water absorption. As presented in figures 4(b) and (c), when alkali concentration increases from 12 to 16 molarity, the compositeâs water absorption increases. This is due to numerous factors : Porosity : As the alkali concentration increases, so does the porosity of the composite material, opening up more channels for water absorption. Fiber-Matrix Interaction : Higher alkali concentrations alter the interaction between SFs and the geopolymer matrix, changing water absorption behavior [29].

caption.p: Response surface plot (a, c, e) indicating the effects of the determining variables on percentage water absorption.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The research delved into an exhaustive examination of the mechanical and physical attributes of SFRGC, encompassing parameters such as compressive strength, splitting tensile strength, and water absorption. The ensuing findings from the experimental inquiry are outlined as follows:(a)
The compressive strength experiences a decline with an escalation in both SF volume percentage (from 5% to 15%), SF length (from 5 mm to 35 mm), and alkali concentration escalates from 12 M to 16 M. However, compressive strength rise when in alkali concentration rise from 8 to 12 M(b)
A notable increase in splitting tensile strength is observed when the proportion of SF volume and the length of SF are heightened from 5% to 15% and 5 mm to 35 mm, respectively.(c)
A rise in water absorption is recorded with an augmentation in the fraction of SF volume and the length of SF from 5% to 15% and 5 mm to 35 mm, respectively.(d)
Water absorption demonstrates an increase with an elevation in alkali concentration from 12 to 16 M, while a decrease is observed when the alkali concentration rises from 8 to 12 M.

sec.title: Conflict of interest

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: All data that support the findings of this study are included within the article (and any supplementary files).

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: No funding was received for conducting this study. No funds, grants, or other support was received.

sec.title: Declaration
sec.p: The authors declare that the research presented in this paper is original, and all data and findings are accurately reported. No conflicts of interest exist, and the manuscript has not been previously published or submitted elsewhere.

sec.title: Supplementary information
sec.p: Raw data, data sets, and databases used, developed, or contributed to during article research. These can be posted to a journalâs additional materials section, although if they are particularly large, a description with links to the information rather than the content itself may be preferred.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: Compliance with the principles outlined in the Declaration of Helsinki and other relevant ethical guidelines. Measures will be taken to ensure the privacy and confidentiality of participantsâ personal information and data. Any potential conflicts of interest will be disclosed and managed appropriately.
